title: Why do medina streets feel narrower than the map suggests?

sections.content: Maps show distance. They don't show texture, shadow, or the compression of attention. A medina street that measures three meters wide can feel like one meter when walls rise four stories, when overhangs block sky, when goods spill from doorways, and when you're navigating around people, carts, and motorcycles simultaneously.

sections.heading: Vertical compression
sections.content: Traditional medina construction maximizes shade. Buildings lean inward at upper floors. Covered passages (sabats) bridge streets entirely. The ratio of height to width creates a canyon effect that European cities rarely replicate. Your peripheral vision fills with wall, not sky.

sections.heading: Horizontal clutter
sections.content: The street is not just circulation space. It's storage, display, workspace, and social room. A nominally three-meter passage becomes a one-meter navigable channel between stacked goods, seated craftsmen, and parked motorcycles. The map shows the container. You experience what's left after everything else claims its share.

title: Why does Marrakech feel hotter, slower, and louder than other cities?

sections.content: Marrakech sits at the edge of the Sahara, at 450 meters elevation, surrounded by the High Atlas. Summer temperatures exceed 45°C. The city's rhythm adapts to this reality, not to your schedule.

sections.heading: Heat shapes everything
sections.content: When outdoor temperatures become dangerous, activity retreats indoors or into shade. The midday lull isn't laziness—it's thermal survival. Evening becomes the productive time. The city genuinely wakes after sunset because that's when human activity becomes physically sustainable.

sections.heading: Sound accumulates differently
sections.content: Dense construction, hard surfaces, and narrow streets create acoustic environments that absorb nothing. Sound bounces and compounds. A motorcycle in an alley registers like a motorcycle in your room. The call to prayer from five nearby mosques arrives as overlapping waves, not a single signal.

title: Why does silence sound different here than at home?

sections.content: What you call silence at home is actually the hum of insulation, sealed windows, HVAC systems, and sound-absorbing materials. Here, silence means the absence of human activity, not the presence of acoustic engineering.

sections.heading: Materials don't absorb
sections.content: Tadelakt, zellige, concrete, and plaster reflect sound. Carpets are decorative, not acoustic. Windows are single-pane or absent. The building envelope is porous. When sound stops, you hear the building itself: the settling of old wood, water in distant pipes, pigeons on the roof.

sections.heading: Night silence is different
sections.content: At 3am, medina silence has texture. You hear the absence of motorcycles, the distant bark of a dog, the murmur of a television through a wall. This is not the sealed quiet of a modern apartment. It's the silence of a city sleeping with its windows open.

title: Why do riads feel cooler inside than outside, even without AC?

sections.content: The riad is a climate machine designed over centuries. It works through mass, geometry, water, and airflow—not electricity.

sections.heading: Thermal mass
sections.content: Thick earthen walls absorb heat slowly during the day and release it slowly at night. The interior temperature lags the exterior by hours. When it's 42°C outside at 2pm, walls that absorbed coolness overnight might still register 26°C on their inner surface.

sections.heading: Courtyard dynamics
sections.content: The central courtyard creates a microclimate. Hot air rises and escapes upward. Cooler air, especially at night, sinks into the courtyard and flows into surrounding rooms. A fountain or pool adds evaporative cooling—water absorbing heat as it evaporates, lowering air temperature by several degrees.

sections.heading: Shade geometry
sections.content: The courtyard is sized so that direct sun reaches the floor only briefly at midday in summer. Galleries and overhangs shade walls most of the day. The building protects itself from its own climate.

title: Why do shopkeepers shout but then ignore you when you enter?

sections.content: The call is not a greeting. It's a signal in a marketplace economy of attention. Once you've entered, the dynamic shifts.

sections.heading: The call as filter
sections.content: Shouting from the doorway identifies who responds. Tourists hesitate or look. Locals walk past without acknowledgment. The call sorts traffic into prospects and passersby. It's efficient, not rude.

sections.heading: Inside is different
sections.content: Once you're inside, the shopkeeper often retreats. This isn't neglect—it's space. Aggressive selling to someone already in the shop signals desperation. The sophisticated approach is to let you look, answer questions when asked, and begin negotiation only when you show genuine interest. Ignoring you is a form of respect for your autonomy and a signal of confidence in the goods.

title: Why does the city wake up late after lunch?

sections.content: The post-lunch lull isn't cultural affectation. It's thermal logic. When outdoor temperatures peak between 1pm and 4pm, reducing activity is the rational response.

sections.heading: Heat cycles
sections.content: Peak heat arrives after solar noon, as accumulated thermal mass radiates back. The hottest part of the day is 2-4pm, not noon. Working through this period requires air conditioning or physical risk. Traditional commerce closes, reopens around 5pm, and continues until 9pm or later.

sections.heading: Meal timing follows
sections.content: Lunch is the main meal, eaten between 1-3pm. Digestion in heat demands rest. The combination of thermal and metabolic load makes the siesta functional, not indulgent. The city restarts when both temperatures and digestion permit.

title: Why are Moroccan houses inward-facing, not outward?

sections.content: The street-facing blank wall is not hostile. It's a deliberate separation between public and private life, with climate and social logic both supporting the design.

sections.heading: Privacy as architecture
sections.content: Islamic residential tradition emphasizes household privacy. The home is a protected interior, not a display. Windows face the courtyard, not the street. This isn't about hiding—it's about maintaining a boundary between family life and commercial or public space.

sections.heading: Climate logic
sections.content: Street-facing windows would admit noise, dust, heat, and direct sun. The courtyard provides light, air, and outlook without these costs. The blank exterior wall is also the thickest, providing maximum thermal mass against the hottest exposure.

sections.heading: Security through opacity
sections.content: A house that reveals nothing from outside offers nothing to assess. Wealth, occupancy, and vulnerability are invisible. This was practical in historical contexts of instability and remains practical in dense urban environments.

title: Why do so many streets end in walls or dead ends?

sections.content: The dead-end street (derb) isn't failed planning. It's a different kind of planning entirely—one that prioritizes neighborhood over circulation.

sections.heading: Residential logic
sections.content: A derb serves only the households on it. Through-traffic is impossible. This creates a semi-private street where children play, neighbors gather, and strangers are immediately visible. The dead end is a security feature, not a planning error.

sections.heading: Organic growth
sections.content: Medinas grew by accretion, not by plan. Each house was built to serve its household, with access as needed. The resulting network optimizes for residential privacy and commercial access along main arteries, not for automotive through-traffic that didn't exist when the city was built.

sections.heading: Legibility for locals
sections.content: Residents don't need through-routes. They know which derb leads where. The complexity that confuses visitors protects residents from unwanted traffic—foot, vehicle, or commercial. Illegibility to outsiders is a feature, not a bug.

title: Why do public toilets smell a certain way?

sections.content: The smell is usually not from waste itself, but from drainage infrastructure that cannot fully separate waste gases from occupied space.

sections.heading: Trap failures
sections.content: Water traps—U-bends that hold water to block sewer gases—require consistent water flow. In intermittently used facilities, traps dry out. In hot climates, evaporation is faster. A dry trap is an open pipe to the sewer.

sections.heading: Ventilation limits
sections.content: Modern plumbing relies on vent stacks that allow sewer gases to escape above roof level. Retrofitted facilities often lack proper venting. Gases that should exit through the roof instead migrate through the nearest available opening—which is the fixture itself.

sections.heading: Maintenance economics
sections.content: Public facilities face a gap between usage intensity and maintenance resources. High traffic, limited budgets, and intermittent water supply create conditions where smells accumulate faster than intervention.

title: Why do cats outnumber dogs in these cities?

sections.content: The cat population reflects cultural tolerance, ecological function, and urban structure. The dog population reflects different constraints.

sections.heading: Cultural framework
sections.content: In Islamic tradition, cats are regarded as clean animals. The Prophet Muhammad treated cats kindly, and hadith literature establishes their positive status. Dogs, while not prohibited, carry associations with impurity in some interpretive traditions. This creates different thresholds for tolerance in public space.

sections.heading: Ecological niche
sections.content: Cats control rodent populations in dense urban environments with open food systems. Markets, restaurants, and households produce waste that would otherwise support rats and mice. Cats occupy this niche naturally and are tolerated or encouraged for their function.

sections.heading: Urban structure
sections.content: Cats navigate vertical space—walls, rooftops, narrow ledges. Dogs require horizontal territory. The medina's three-dimensional complexity favors cats. They can access food sources, escape routes, and sleeping spots that dogs cannot reach.

title: Why does tap water taste or smell weird sometimes?

sections.content: Water chemistry varies by source, treatment, and delivery infrastructure. What you taste is usually minerals or chlorine, not contamination.

sections.heading: Mineral profiles
sections.content: Marrakech water comes from multiple sources—aquifers, the Tensift river system, and Atlas mountain runoff. Each has different mineral content. Seasonal variation in source mix changes the taste. High mineral content (hard water) is safe but unfamiliar to visitors from soft-water regions.

sections.heading: Chlorine persistence
sections.content: Municipal treatment uses chlorine to ensure safety through the distribution network. In hot conditions, chlorine dissipates faster from stored water but remains stronger in freshly drawn supplies. Time of day and proximity to treatment affects what you smell.

sections.heading: Building infrastructure
sections.content: Rooftop tanks, common in older buildings, store water that sits in heat. This can affect taste without affecting safety. Older pipes may contribute mineral or metallic notes. The building's plumbing is often older than any single occupant.

title: Why do meals feel later than you're used to?

sections.content: Meal timing follows heat cycles and social patterns, not clock conventions imported from different climates.

sections.heading: Heat-adjusted scheduling
sections.content: Eating a large meal in peak heat is physically uncomfortable. Lunch moves to early afternoon (1-3pm) when shade is available. Dinner moves to 9pm or later, when outdoor temperatures finally break. These times seem late only relative to expectations formed elsewhere.

sections.heading: Social meal logic
sections.content: The main meal is a household gathering, not a quick refuel. Preparing and eating together takes time. Starting dinner at 9pm means finishing by 10:30 or 11pm—not unreasonable when the city remains active until midnight and the next morning doesn't demand an early start.

title: Why do people eat bread with everything, even sweet things?

sections.content: Bread is not a side dish. It's a utensil, a filler, and a texture anchor. Its role in the meal is functional, not ceremonial.

sections.heading: Bread as tool
sections.content: Traditional eating uses bread to scoop, grip, and transport food. Tagines, salads, and dips are designed for bread contact. Cutlery is optional; bread is not. This is practical technology for eating shared dishes.

sections.heading: Caloric extension
sections.content: Bread extends expensive proteins and vegetables. A tagine that might serve two with forks serves four with bread. Bread makes modest quantities of flavorful food into complete meals. This is economic logic, not lack of sophistication.

sections.heading: Textural pairing
sections.content: Sweet pastries and preserves with bread is textural contrast, not confusion. The chew of bread against the softness of msemen with honey, or bread with amlou (almond butter), provides satisfaction that the sweet alone doesn't deliver.

title: Why doesn't mint tea taste like mint tea everywhere?

sections.content: Mint tea is not a recipe. It's a practice with regional variation in ingredients, proportions, and technique.

sections.heading: Mint varieties
sections.content: Moroccan mint (nana) differs from spearmint and peppermint. Seasonal variation in freshness affects flavor intensity. Winter tea often uses dried mint or different herbs (sheeba/wormwood, louiza/verbena) that shift the profile entirely.

sections.heading: Sugar calibration
sections.content: Traditional preparation uses substantial sugar—far more than most visitors expect. Reduced sugar at tourist-oriented establishments changes the balance. Authentic local preparation might be sweeter than you'd make yourself.

sections.heading: Gunpowder tea base
sections.content: The green tea base (Chinese gunpowder tea) varies in quality and age. Stale tea produces flat results. The ratio of tea to mint to sugar shifts regionally and personally. Each household has its own hand.

title: Why does the ground feel warmer underfoot than the air?

sections.content: Surfaces absorb and store solar radiation. They release it slowly, remaining warm hours after air temperature drops.

sections.heading: Material heat retention
sections.content: Stone, tile, and concrete absorb heat throughout the day. By evening, surface temperatures can exceed air temperature by 10°C or more. Walking barefoot or in thin sandals, you feel the stored heat directly. The ground remembers the afternoon sun.

sections.heading: Night cooling lag
sections.content: Air cools faster than mass. After sunset, air temperature drops while surfaces continue radiating stored heat. This creates the sensation of warm ground beneath cool air—a thermal inversion that persists until well after midnight in summer.

title: Why does heat feel more exhausting here than elsewhere?

sections.content: Heat stress depends on temperature, humidity, sun exposure, and exertion. Marrakech combines high temperatures with intense solar radiation and unfamiliar exertion patterns.

sections.heading: Solar load
sections.content: Direct sun adds heat beyond air temperature. Your body receives radiation from above and from heated surfaces around you. Shade isn't just cooler—it removes a significant heat input that air temperature alone doesn't capture.

sections.heading: Exertion differences
sections.content: Visitors walk more than usual, on unfamiliar surfaces, while processing new information continuously. This cognitive and physical load generates more body heat than daily routine at home. You're working harder than you realize.

sections.heading: Adaptation takes time
sections.content: Acclimatization to heat requires 7-14 days. Blood plasma volume increases, sweat efficiency improves, and heart rate response moderates. In the first few days, your body works harder to achieve the same cooling. Exhaustion is physiological, not weakness.

title: Why do cockroaches show up even in clean places?

sections.content: Cockroaches are endemic to warm, dense cities. Their presence indicates climate and infrastructure, not the cleanliness of any individual building.

sections.heading: Climate suitability
sections.content: Cockroach species common to Marrakech evolved in warm, humid environments. Mediterranean and Saharan edge climates provide ideal conditions: consistent warmth, seasonal moisture, and abundant organic matter. They would exist here regardless of human hygiene standards.

sections.heading: Infrastructure connectivity
sections.content: The medina is a continuous built mass. Drainage channels, shared walls, and gaps in century-old construction create pathways between buildings. No individual property can fully seal itself from neighbors. A cockroach in your bathroom may have traveled from three buildings away.

sections.heading: Population management, not elimination
sections.content: Professional pest control reduces populations but cannot eliminate them from an interconnected urban fabric. The goal is management, not eradication. Seeing one cockroach does not indicate infestation; it indicates that the building exists in an ecosystem where cockroaches are native.

title: Why does walking 500 meters feel like 2 kilometers?

sections.content: Distance perception depends on more than meters. It depends on terrain, navigation load, and sensory density.

sections.heading: Terrain friction
sections.content: Uneven surfaces, steps, slopes, and obstacles slow physical progress. You cover the same distance with more steps, more attention, and more energy. Your body registers the effort, not the map distance.

sections.heading: Navigation load
sections.content: Constant decision-making at intersections, dead ends, and ambiguous turnings demands attention that straight-line walking doesn't. Mental effort feels like physical effort. A confusing 500 meters exhausts like a straightforward kilometer.

sections.heading: Sensory density
sections.content: More information per meter means more processing. Shops, people, sounds, smells, and hazards demand attention continuously. Your brain works harder per unit distance. This cognitive load translates to perceived physical fatigue.

title: Why does Google Maps mislead you more here than at home?

sections.content: Digital maps assume a relationship between mapped paths and walkable routes that doesn't hold in organic urban fabric.

sections.heading: Mapping limitations
sections.content: Medina streets were not surveyed systematically. GPS accuracy degrades in narrow streets between tall buildings. Some paths are seasonal (covered during markets), conditional (closed at night), or ambiguous (through private property with informal access). The map shows a path; reality requires permission.

sections.heading: Legibility mismatch
sections.content: At home, you confirm map directions with street signs, building numbers, and visible landmarks. Here, signs are sparse, numbers follow different logic, and landmarks you can see on the map (a mosque, a fountain) may be invisible at street level until you're beside them. The map is correct; you can't confirm it.

sections.heading: Pedestrian vs. overhead view
sections.content: Maps show the city from above. You navigate from within. A passage that looks like a street from above may be a covered souk with multiple internal turns. The map's path is approximate; the actual route requires local knowledge or trial and error.

title: Why do locals turn right where tourists go left?

sections.content: Locals navigate by felt distance, not measured distance. The shortest path isn't the straightest—it's the one that flows.

sections.heading: Learned shortcuts
sections.content: Residents know which passages are faster at which times. A longer-looking route might avoid a congested market, a steep staircase, or a dead end that forces backtracking. The local path optimizes for total effort, including knowledge you don't have.

sections.heading: Rhythm navigation
sections.content: Familiar routes are walked without conscious navigation. The body knows when to turn. This releases attention for conversation, thought, or awareness of surroundings. Taking the tourist's logical route requires active wayfinding—a cost the local's habitual route avoids.

sections.heading: Social paths
sections.content: Regular routes pass familiar faces, favored shops, and useful services. The local's path serves social and practical purposes beyond simple transit. They're not just getting there; they're participating in a daily pattern.

title: Why do shop aisles seem emptier but more crowded?

sections.content: The perception of crowding depends on space conventions you've internalized without noticing.

sections.heading: Proxemic differences
sections.content: Comfortable interpersonal distance varies by culture. What feels crowded to you may feel normal to someone accustomed to higher social density. Your discomfort is a mismatch of spatial expectations, not an objective measure of crowding.

sections.heading: Multi-use space
sections.content: Aisles in souks are not just circulation. They're display space, negotiation space, and social space. A sparse-looking shop may feel crowded because the aisle is also where you're expected to stop, handle goods, and talk to the merchant. You're occupying multi-purpose space.

sections.heading: Visual compression
sections.content: Goods filling vertical surfaces create visual density that registers as physical density. A shop with fewer people but more visible merchandise feels more crowded than an empty-walled space with more people spread through it.

title: Why does it feel rude to refuse tea but you don't want any?

sections.content: Tea is not a beverage transaction. It's a relational gesture. Refusing tea refuses the relationship, not the drink.

sections.heading: Tea as presence
sections.content: Offering tea signals: I see you, I acknowledge you, I'm prepared to spend time with you. Accepting means: I recognize this, I'm willing to be present. The tea itself matters less than the mutual commitment to occupy the same space without hurry.

sections.heading: Commerce and courtesy
sections.content: In commercial contexts, tea creates space before negotiation. It establishes that you're a guest before you're a customer. Refusing tea signals: I don't have time for courtesy, get to the transaction. This feels abrupt even when you don't intend it.

sections.heading: Practical exits
sections.content: You can accept tea without drinking it. Hold the glass, take small sips, let it cool untouched. The gesture matters. You can leave after one glass with thanks. The obligation is to accept the offer, not to finish the pot.

title: Why does time feel elastic here?

sections.content: Clock time is one technology for organizing activity. It's not the only one. Here, event-based and relational timing coexist with scheduled time.

sections.heading: Event-based scheduling
sections.content: Things happen when conditions are right, not when clocks dictate. A meeting starts when everyone arrives. A shop opens when the owner finishes breakfast. The prayer call provides five daily time anchors more reliable than watch-checking.

sections.heading: Relational time
sections.content: Ending a conversation to meet a schedule signals that the schedule matters more than the person. In relational time, the current interaction deserves its full duration. Being late to the next thing is the cost of being present to the current one.

sections.heading: Your experience of drift
sections.content: You're not wrong that things don't happen when expected. You're using a timing system that doesn't have priority here. The elasticity you feel is the mismatch between your internalized schedule-orientation and a context with different timing logic.

title: Why does everything feel more intense at dusk?

sections.content: Dusk in Marrakech is a convergence point: thermal relief, social emergence, and sensory transition happening simultaneously.

sections.heading: Thermal release
sections.content: After hours of heat, the first cooling triggers a collective exhale. Bodies that have been conserving energy begin to move. The city shifts from endurance mode to activity mode.

sections.heading: Social emergence
sections.content: People who spent the afternoon indoors come out. Streets that were sparse fill. Markets reopen. The social density increases rapidly, concentrating human activity into the comfortable hours.

sections.heading: Light and shadow
sections.content: The low sun creates long shadows, warm tones, and high contrast. Surfaces glow. Depth perception shifts. The visual environment becomes more dramatic without any change in the physical city. Your perception is heightened by the light itself.

title: Why do Moroccan cities feel layered, not organized?

sections.content: The medina is not a designed city. It's an accumulated one. Each era left its mark without erasing the previous ones.

sections.heading: Historical strata
sections.content: A single street may contain walls from the 12th century, doors from the 17th, electrical wiring from the 1960s, and satellite dishes from last year. The city is a physical record of continuous occupation, each layer adapted to rather than replaced by the next.

sections.heading: Planning without master plans
sections.content: Growth followed rules—religious, social, practical—without a single coordinating authority. Each household, each generation, each ruler added according to the logic of their moment. The result is coherent without being systematic. Patterns emerge from repeated local decisions, not from imposed order.

sections.heading: Reading the layers
sections.content: The confusion visitors feel is pattern recognition trying to find order that isn't there in that form. The city makes sense as accumulation, not as design. Once you see it as a record rather than a plan, the layers become legible on their own terms.

title: Why do medina walls feel like memory?

sections.content: The walls are records. Every crack, patch, and modification tells part of the story of the lives lived against them.

sections.heading: Material accumulation
sections.content: Tadelakt darkens with age and touch. Whitewash layers accumulate annual reapplication. Repairs reveal earlier states. The wall is a physical document of maintenance, neglect, damage, and repair stretching back centuries. You're looking at time made visible.

sections.heading: Use patterns
sections.content: Wear marks where shoulders brush, smoothed corners where hands turn, faded areas where sun falls consistently—these traces record repetition. Bodies have moved along these walls for generations. The paths are worn into the surfaces.

sections.heading: Memory without intention
sections.content: The wall doesn't mean to record anything. It simply persists while life happens against it. The sense of memory you feel is pattern recognition: you're reading evidence of lives without knowing whose. The wall is an inadvertent archive.

title: Why do neighborhoods have their own invisible rules?

sections.content: Each derb and quarter operates as a micro-community with norms developed among people who know each other. These norms are invisible to outsiders because they're enforced socially, not legally.

sections.heading: Social micro-polities
sections.content: A residential derb knows its residents. Who belongs, who doesn't, and what behavior is acceptable are maintained through observation and gossip. A stranger's presence is noticed immediately. A resident's misbehavior is sanctioned through reputation, not regulation.

sections.heading: Spatial conventions
sections.content: Where children play, where goods are stored, where washing hangs, which doors are left open—these are negotiated among neighbors, not written down. The conventions seem invisible because they're enforced by expectation, not signage.

sections.heading: Outsider uncertainty
sections.content: You feel the rules without seeing them because you can sense social observation you don't understand. The discomfort of possibly violating unknown norms is accurate: you don't know the rules, and the community is watching to see if you'll break them.

title: Why do markets feel alive but not loud?

sections.content: The souk sustains activity without the acoustic chaos of modern retail. The difference is in rhythm, not volume.

sections.heading: Embedded commerce
sections.content: Shops are also workshops. The craftsman making the object is also selling it. There's no separation between production and transaction, which means fewer surfaces dedicated to pure display, less competitive signaling, more functional presence.

sections.heading: Rhythm over competition
sections.content: Adjacent shops often sell the same goods. Competition is not about capturing attention through noise—it's about relationship, quality, and negotiation. Shouting for attention signals desperation. Calm presence signals confidence.

sections.heading: Movement as sound
sections.content: The souk's aliveness is kinetic: movement, activity, the clink of tools, the shuffle of feet, the murmur of negotiation. This is a different acoustic quality than loudspeaker-driven retail. The life is visible and audible, but at human scale.

title: Why is there white powdery stuff on the walls?

sections.content: The white crystalline deposits appearing on riad walls are saltpetre (potassium nitrate) or efflorescence—mineral salts drawn to the surface by moisture movement. This is not dirt, mold, or poor maintenance. It's chemistry acting on old construction.

sections.heading: How it forms
sections.content: Water inside walls dissolves natural salts present in earth, lime, and masonry. As moisture migrates toward the surface and evaporates, it leaves salts behind. These crystallize into white, powdery, sometimes fluffy deposits. The drier the air, the faster evaporation occurs, and the more visible the deposits become.

sections.heading: Why riads are vulnerable
sections.content: Traditional construction used no damp-proof membranes. Buildings before 1930—and riads are centuries older—allow moisture to rise through walls from the ground. Earthen materials (pisé, adobe) and lime-based plasters contain salts naturally. The combination of porous materials, rising damp, and intense evaporation creates ideal conditions for efflorescence.

sections.heading: Climate factors
sections.content: Marrakech's climate intensifies the cycle. Seasonal rains introduce moisture; hot, dry months pull it out rapidly. Each cycle deposits more salts. The walls breathe—this is why they regulate temperature so well—but breathing also means salts migrate continuously to the surface.

sections.heading: Treatment, not elimination
sections.content: Saltpetre can be brushed away, but it returns unless the moisture source is addressed. Modern interventions include hydrophobic resin injection to block rising damp. However, in historic buildings, some efflorescence is simply accepted as the cost of authentic construction. The walls are working as designed; the white deposits are evidence of that work.

title: Why is my riad so far from Jemaa el-Fna?

sections.content: The Marrakech medina contains over 1,000 riads and guesthouses spread across multiple distinct neighborhoods. Jemaa el-Fna is one point in a large urban fabric—not the center of everything.

sections.heading: Scale of the medina
sections.content: The historic medina covers approximately 600 hectares within its walls. Walking from one edge to another can take 40 minutes or more. Riads exist throughout this area—near souks, near neighborhood mosques, near tanneries, near gates. Jemaa el-Fna is the tourist focal point, but it's not where most of the medina's residential and commercial life happens.

sections.heading: The 1,000+ riad reality
sections.content: Estimates place the number of riads and guesthouses in the medina between 800 and 1,200. Only a fraction of these are within five minutes of the main square. Many excellent riads are 15, 20, or 30 minutes' walk away—which means you're staying in an actual neighborhood, not in a tourist zone.

sections.heading: Walking times are real
sections.content: A riad in the northern medina (near Bab Doukkala) or the southern quarters (near the Mellah) may require 20-40 minutes to reach Jemaa el-Fna on foot. This is not misrepresentation; it's geography. The medina is large. Walking is the only way to move through most of it. Taxis can only reach the edges, at the gates (babs) in the walls.

sections.heading: What distance offers
sections.content: Distance from the square often means quieter nights, more authentic neighborhood life, and lower prices. You trade convenience for calm. Some travelers prefer to be in the center of activity; others prefer to retreat from it. Both are valid—but understanding the medina's scale prevents surprise.
